data.title: Starting an animation at a certain time with the API
data.description: Using the Haiku Developer API
data.body:
You can control the playback of your animation with the timeline. You can access your component's timeline using: haikuComponent.getDefaultTimeline()

There’s more info in the docs, but here are some methods that may come in handy:


.play() -> void

Play this timeline at whatever frame it's currently at. (This does not reset the playhead to 0.)

.seek(milliseconds: Number) -> void

Jump to a specific time (in milliseconds) in the timeline.

Note that this locks playback to the specified frame. Use .gotoAndPlay if you want it to continue playing from that point.

.gotoAndPlay(milliseconds: Number) -> void

Seek a specific frame, and play from that point.

.gotoAndStop(milliseconds: Number) -> void

Seek to a specific frame, and stop the timeline at that point.

data.title: Changing colors
data.description: Can I change the stage's background color or an asset's color?
data.body:
Yes! You can change the stage's background color or an asset's color in Animator by adding a property in the timeline and entering the:

  • Hex value. For example #EE4747 

  • RGBA value. For example rgba(238, 71, 71, 0.6)

To change the background color of the stage, you need to click on the [+] button below "Main" in the library, select the "Background color" option, and enter the color's value.

You can also change the color of an instantiated slice by adding the "fill" property.

Apart from background color and fill, there are a lot of other properties you can add to your elements. Explore all of the options!


Tip: Remember that the "Color" property works the same as in CSS. It's used to change the color of text.

Gradients

Can I change the gradient fill on a shape along the timeline?

There is a way! We don’t provide a UI for doing this sort of thing (yet!), but you can use Code mode to create this effect on any type of parameterized gradient supported by SVG. Here’s an example you could fork and check out: https://share.haiku.ai/u/SashaTheOrg/greatient

data.title: Rotating slices
data.description: How can I rotate my slice / element?
data.body:
It's possible to rotate elements in two ways:

1- You can select an element directly by clicking it on stage and holding cmd to rotate. Tip: If you also hold Shift you will rotate your element by fixed increments.

2- You can modify the element's [Rotation Z] value in radians. Tip: If you modify the [Rotation X] and [Rotation Y] values, you can create 3D rotations!

data.title: Reorganizing layers
data.description: How can I change the order of my layers / slices / elements / shapes?
data.body:
You can re-order your layers in three ways:

1- You can hover over an element's name in the timeline to display the [rearrange] button. By clicking and dragging you can move that layer up or down.


2- You can modify the element's [Style Z-Index] value. The higher the number, the further to the top the element will be.


3- You can use the contextual menu on the stage to move your element front and back.

data.title: Frames and milliseconds
data.description: Can I switch from frames to milliseconds in the timeline?
data.body:
Animator runs at 60fps, so you can multiply the frame number by 60 to get the milliseconds (ms). 

Also, you can click on the words "FRAMES | SECONDS" near the top-left of the timeline to toggle the units shown in the timeline.

Note: If you switch to milliseconds, the frame actions window will still show the frame number, not the ms.

data.title: Selecting slices
data.description: How can I select an object in the canvas when there are many and they are at the same position?
data.body:
You can select elements you've instantiated by dragging and dropping them from the library onto the stage in two ways:

  1. Directly clicking on the shape, on the stage.

  2. Clicking on the shape's name on the timeline's properties panel. This is very useful when you have multiple slices on the stage, especially if they are stacked.

3. Locking the group or layer that you don't want to select, click and drag on the stage to select all, and you'll see that the locked layer/group doesn't get selected.

After doing all the adjustments you need to your animation (e.g. grouping), you can unlock the layer.

TIP: You can lock layers by clicking on the [lock] icon below the asset's name in the timeline. This also disables all "pointer events" on that element.

data.title: Embedding your animation in a dev project
data.description: Will the code in my project auto-update if I change my animation?
data.body:
All of your Animator projects live in ~/.haiku/projects/YOURUSERNAME/PROJECTNAME — and the project files are plain JavaScript.

You can symlink them into your code projects (React/Vue/Angular), for example with npm link or yarn link , and then any changes you make in Animator will propagate through your dev project.

You will find instructions on how to embed your animation on the "Publish" modal.

You can also do this by command line:

cd ~/.haiku/projects/YOUR_ANIMATOR_USERNAME/YOUR_ANIMATOR_PROJECT_NAME
npm link
cd YOUR_CODEBASE
npm link @haiku/YOUR_LOWERCASE_USERNAME-YOUR_LOWERCASE_PROJECT_NAME


This will create a symlink from where your Animator project sits on disk to your node_modules directory inside your codebase.  As long as your dev server is configured to reload upon changes in node_modules (often but not always the case), you should see your codebase reload any time you make changes to that Animator project, including from the Animator-watched Sketch file.

Tip: The Angular compiler doesn’t follow symlinks by default, so if you’re not using symlinks already, you’ll probably need to add the preserveSymlinks build option to your angular.json.

See here for details: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/10735#issuecomment-387636803

data.title: Using CodePen to view your animation
data.description: Will CodePen auto-update if I change a Sketch element in my animation?
data.body:
When you publish your animation, you can click on the "Shareable link" and see it render in share.haiku.ai. 

From there, you can click on the [CodePen] button to open your animation in CodePen.

If you change your animation,  it won’t auto-update in CodePen; you’ll need to create a new one. However, the share links that end in /latest should update every time you publish.

data.title: Change username / email address
data.description: Can I change my username or my email address after I create my account?
data.body:
Change my username

Unfortunately, we do not support changing usernames.  The complexities span into our backend, where usernames act as primary identifiers across several systems, including the custom git & npm infrastructure that back each project.

The cleanest course of action I can recommend for this hand-off is the following:

  1. for each project you want to carry over to the new account, temporarily mark it PUBLIC. If you want to fork your Private projects, without editing their privacy settings, please check this article.

  2. create a new account with the desired username

  3. from the new account, visit each published (public) project from the old account, and fork it to the new account

  4. log back into the original account, and mark projects private again [Note that while public, projects could theoretically be forked by other users.  This is unlikely but not impossible.] 

Assuming you want the new account to be Pro and the old one not to be, we can also assist with transferring the billing.  The easiest way would be to issue a coupon code for the new account to cover the current term you've already paid for (month or year), apply that to the new account, then cancel the subscription for the old account.

Change my email address

If you want to change the email address associated with your Animator account, you need to go to https://account.haikuforteams.com/ and log in.

data.title: [Troubleshooting] Lottie
data.description: Known issues when using Animator + Lottie
data.body:
Known issues

Any discrepancy between Animator & Lottie could be a limitation of Lottie support. In general, the limitations of the Lottie integration are documented here. 

Lottie + Animator doesn't support

  • 3D rotation. You could try using negative scale.x and scale.y to fake the rotation — which would be supported in Lottie, or removing 3D transforms from your Animator project, e.g. any Rotation Y, Rotation X, or Translation Z properties.

  • Drop shadows on iOS or Android.

  • Masking.

  • Subcomponent timeline control. As implemented, subcomponents play once.

  • Dynamic expressions — flat JSON Lottie format only supports static and doesn’t have helpers/summonables.

  • Using PNG or JPG on your Design tool file

  • CSS stroke dash-array

  • Interactions, it only supports animations. Lottie has no way to support Actions or Expressions from Haiku Animator, and Lottie also doesn't offer a consistent cross-platform API for controlling playback. Some Lottie users have hacked into it and found ways to control the Lottie playhead with swift/objective C/java/Kotlin, which you can also do with Haiku Animator Lottie exports.  If you want to use the Actions you author inside Haiku Animator on iOS or Android, the best option is to use Animator Core and embed your projects in webviews. 

Testing

Once you've created your animation, please export to Lottie and test the obtained Lottie JSON at https://lottiefiles.com/preview

When a Lottie export doesn't work, but there is an exported blob of JSON  — it's almost certainly a Lottie version issue. The Lottie runtime has introduced several breaking changes across versions, without any clear notification or documentation of these changes.  This is further complicated by inconsistent adherence to versions across Lottie's iOS/Android/Web players. For a fix, I would recommend trying an older version of Lottie, closer to the versions listed in this section of our Lottie docs: https://docs.haikuforteams.com/embedding-and-using-haiku/lottie.html#limitations

More information

Will Lottie support dynamic features soon?

We don't expect Lottie to become a full application runtime. They are pretty intent on staying the course as an After-Effects-to-Animation solution. We agree that full cross-platform native runtimes, including interactions, would be awesome.  As you might imagine, it's also a lot of work.

In the meantime, Haiku Core is the Web library that works as a full UI runtime, including support for user interactions & executing code.  Core is also the exact renderer used inside Animator itself, so what you see is precisely what you get.  By exporting to Lottie, we essentially have to remove the interactive/code pieces.

Native mobile interactivity is coming, but in the future. In the meantime, you could try using a WKWebView in iOS (simple HTMLString to embed the animation into the WebView) .We've had users report that embedding WKWebViews that render Animator components perform very well in native iOS apps. You can pass data into the Animator component from Swift/Objc via postMessage.

Older versions

It's not currently possible to export the animations to a .json that's compliant with older Lottie versions. 

Theoretically a more modern lottie.json exported by Animator should be compliant (and backwards compatible) with a previous version of Lottie, but if it doesn't work that's about the end of the line. Lottie is so generous with breaking changes that tracking each of their versions separately is out of reach for our small team. We recommend upgrading Lottie inside your project if that's an option.

Tips

Sizing

The “Size X” and “Size Y” you set on the Main component (you can address these directly using the timeline via Stage sizing) are written out as the “composition dimensions” of the Lottie file (the Lottie adapters for Android and iOS have their own sizing conventions). So, the artboard size you set in Animator on the main component becomes the “pixel dimensions” of the Lottie animation file. 

Closing paths

For Lottie to render your designs correctly, you need to "Close paths" in Sketch.

If you run into any additional issues you can contact us with the share.haiku.ai URL we can look into that project with more specificity.

Strokes

In your design tool (Sketch/Figma/AI) — convert that stroke to a fill. It's possible the Lottie export will then work as expected.   If that doesn't work, you could also try converting the stroke to a raster image. There are certain vector artifacts/elements that Lottie won't render, so these work-arounds may get you there.

data.title: Stage sizing
data.description: How can I adjust the size of the stage / canvas / art-board?
data.body:
You can adjust the size of the Stage in two ways:

Click + drag

If you click on the Stage's name, sizing controls will appear.

Edit property in the timeline

The first row in the timeline's properties panel is called "Main" and it affects the stage. From there you can manually input the value in pixels to adjust the stage size.


TIP: Use vector artwork if your design allows for it, so you can scale the published component to any size maintaining the same aspect ratio.


Note: Sometimes the stage size may accidentally be set in a future keyframe instead of frame 0, causing unexpected results when re-opening the project. Check if you have any keyframes set for Size underneath your Main component in the timeline.

data.title: Animated SVG support
data.description: Is it possible to export an animated SVG?
data.body:
Can I export an SVG animation?

Animator does use SVG animations, but it doesn’t export/produce a vanilla.svg file.

Animator uses SVG internally to render what you see in the browser.  SVG by itself is not enough to render the animations or interactions that you create in Animator (we have to augment with HTML + JS + CSS) so "vanilla SVG" isn't a possibility.

We bundle some simple JavaScript to actually execute the animations, which can also handle more complex logic like responding to user input, or your application logic.

Why doesn't Animator support this feature?

The driving mission of Animator is for building interactive animations and UIs; exporting to vanilla SVG would require removing all interactivity, which would be a step in the wrong direction per that mission.

What if I need to export a static SVG?

If you're looking for static vanilla (still) SVG, you should be able to export stills from your vector design tool.

data.title: Mac system requirements
data.description: What at the current system requirements for using Animator in Mac?
data.body: You will need to have OS X/macOS 10.9+, which is the minimum version Electron runs on.

data.title: Browser support
data.description: What fallbacks are in place for older browsers?
data.body:
We support all modern/evergreen browsers. The browsers supported are listed here.

Animator Core (the rendering engine + interactive runtime) does not support IE 11. It was a tough call when we chose to support evergreen browsers only, though IE11 simply doesn't have the capabilities needed to support the things you can do in Animator. 

A fallback could be handled with user agent checks in your website (e.g. if modern browser, show animation; else, show something else).

Note:

Any discrepancy between [Preview] mode in Animator, and a published project on share.haiku.ai should be rare— if there is, it’s likely browser related. Send us a link and we can look into it.

data.title: Is there an easy way to pause the timeline?
data.description: For example: I want to pause the animation on the first frame to wait for an interaction.
data.body:
There’s a couple ways to do that:

  1. Programmatically with your component in production. <MyHaiku haikuOptions=#{{ autoplay: false }}/>

  2. The better way is this though: Go to frame 1 on the timeline gauge and add an action to it with the [+] button that appears above the numbers when you hover them. Then choose ‘pause’ from the snippet options. You can later edit this by clicking on the lightning icon above the number.

Learn more about this in this blog post.

data.title: Troubleshooting: Animator in Mac
data.description: Do I need to have Animator on the Applications folder?
data.body:
Yes, in order for Animator to work correctly, you need to have it installed in the Applications folder.

Otherwise, it will not have all the necessary permissions to complete certain actions. For example, if you have Animator running from Downloads, Animator may not have the permissions necessary to trigger Sketch's SVG exporter.  

Important

You also need to have your design tool (Sketch / Figma / Illustrator) in the Applications folder, for everything to work smoothly.

data.title: Multi-select keyframes
data.description: How can I select several keyframes or tweens at once?
data.body:
You can multi-select keyframes and tweens in two ways:

Shift + click

Marquee selection (click + drag)

data.title: Align slices
data.description: How can I align elements?
data.body:
You can align the slices/elements you bring from Sketch / Figma / Illustrator / SVG in three ways:

Ungroup

Now, you can export more complex groups from your design tool, and ungroup them in Animator to individually animate the different slices that compose the group, while maintaining their original position.

To do this, you need to drag and drop your group from the library to the stage, right-click on the group, and select the option "Ungroup" from the contextual menu (or Cmd+Shift+G).

Snapping

Whenever you move an element or slice, by clicking and dragging it on stage, you will see the snapping guides, which will help you align your slices.

Tip: If you hold cmd the snapping guides will not show.

Align 

You can access the "Align" panel by clicking its button, located at the top bar. You will find different alignment options, including one to align your slices to the stage.

data.title: Rendering your animation in a browser
data.description: Can I see how my animation looks in the browser?
data.body:
To see how your animation renders in a browser, you only need to click on the shareable link you get when you publish your project, or view it on your Showcase profile.

The "share.haiku.ai" link itself does actual rendering in the browser. What you see is the actual code-based animation, not a video of it. 

You can also click the "View on CodePen" link at the bottom-left of the screen to see it stand-alone.

data.title: Public vs private projects
data.description: What's the difference between public and private share links?
data.body:
What is the difference?

When you create a project, you can decide if you want it to be public or private. This determines who can see your project, and what types of interaction people can have with it.

Public projects

  • Can be featured in the Showcase.

  • Appear on your Showcase profile (you can access it by clicking on your username, in the top-right corner of the Showcase) as public.

  • Can be forked by anyone.

Private projects

  • Will not appear on the Showcase.

  • Appear on your Showcase profile as private.

  • Cannot be forked yet. Read more about it here.

  • Only the people with the private share link can see it.

Get the share link

To get your public or private share link, simply publish your project, by clicking the [Publish] button at the top-right corner.

From the publish modal you can check and change your privacy settings, and you can copy your shareable link.

data.title: How can I share my work with others?
data.description: I want to show my animation to a colleague or friend
data.body:
To share your animation, you need to publish your project by clicking the [Publish] button at the top-right corner.

In the Publish modal, you will find different options to send your animation to others.

You can:

  • Send the "Shareable link", which can be public or private.

  • Download or send the link to your animation in a GIF format.

  • Download or send the link to your animation in MP4 (video format). 

  • Coming soon!  Team collaboration features.


Tip: The shareable links you get should point to the latest revision as long as there's a /latest at the end of the URL. If you ever want to point to a specific revision instead, you can remove the /latest.


Note: We don't currently support a .png sequence export.

data.title: Trouble importing slices from Sketch
data.description: Some of my slices are not showing up in the library, why?
data.body:
One possibility is that names are colliding — we rely on Sketch's built-in exporter, which doesn't give a lot of flexibility with names. 

E.g. if you have two elements named the same, you'll only see one of them inside Animator. 

If your slices don't have unique names, (e.g. if two of them are called "Oval") then Sketch's built-in exporter will cause one to overwrite the other.

data.title: GIF Support
data.description: Does Animator support GIFs?
data.body:
Exporting

To save your animation as a GIF, follow these steps:

  1. Once you are done animating, you need to Publish your project by clicking the [Publish] button at the top-right corner.

2. Wait until Animator finishes preparing your GIF (you'll see a progress bar on the GIF button, under "Other").

3. Click on the [GIF] button to open the GIF modal, where you'll be able to preview your animation.

4. If you click on the link at the bottom of the GIF modal, or if you copy and paste it into a browser, you will be able to select where to save it, and then the download will begin.

You can also export GIFs directly to your computer in medium and high quality, from the top menu bar (Project > export).

Tip: You can even do this while you are offline!

Note: Subcomponents not animating in a GIF export is expected. The only way to get subcomponents to play is to render the component in a browser. The same goes for Lottie and Video.

Transparent background

We don’t support transparent backgrounds for GIFs at the moment. One thing you might try is creating your GIF with the same background color you plan to place it on.

data.title: Spacebar uses
data.description: What does pressing the spacebar do?
data.body:
Pressing spacebar does different things:

  • On the stage, space + click + drag pans the stage.

  • On the timeline, space toggles playback.

What you use the spacebar for depends on where your mouse cursor is. If you're hovering over the timeline, spacebar toggles playback. If you're hovering over the stage, spacebar enables click+drag panning.

data.title: Custom curves
data.description: Does Animator support custom animation curves?
data.body:
Yes! Asides from our range of preselected curves, as shown below, we now offer custom animation curves via the Bézier editor. Read more about it here. 

]
